The condo was a 2 bedroom unit on the 11th floor with balconies overlooking Waikiki and the marina. There were 2 bathrooms and a well equipped kitchen. Wifi was available at an additional (minimal) charge. The location was great, at the entrance to Waikiki and it was an easy walk or busride into the heart of it all, but far enough away if we wanted a quiet evening on the balcony. The beach just beyond the Hilton lagoon was very calm and a great place to just laze in the water. With three traveling together, this was a much more economic option than paying for two hotel rooms. We had plenty of space and the ability to bring in groceries for breakfast/snacks saved $$. We would definitely return!

Going to Honolulu again brought concerns about traffic, but the Ilikai Hotel was our oasis. Situated on the end of Waikiki Beach by the Harbor, we were on the 25th floor and had a great view. Our only objection was the two double beds that were not "moveable" so we had to sleep separately. Our itinerary had been planned to include a dinner cruise and a luau, both of which provided shuttles from our hotel. We were a few blocks from the Ala Moana shopping center, so we walked there one day. Rented a car for a day and drove around Oahu to see the "other side" - away from traffic and congestion. All in all, an excellent start to our three weeks in the Islands. The remaining two weeks were spent on Maui.

We were there for 2 weeks in a privately owned condo - and it was great! We had an amazing view of the harbor, full kitchen, and washer/dryer on each floor. We did our own daily cleaning which wasn't a big deal. The location was near a bus line and easy walking to Waikiki sights and the Ala Moana Mall, etc. Would definitely stay there again!

I stayed here for two separate business trips totaling about 20 days and was thoroughly impressed with the entire property. I was extremely skeptical due to the comparatively economical price, but was very pleased with everything about it. I selected a room with a kitchen due to my long stay and it was large, clean and very modern including a full size refrigerator. The room was very modern with the normal amenities you expect nowadays including internet connection, flat screen tv and stone tile bathroom floors. The hotel is also located within walking distance of the beach and the international market area as well as quite a few really nice restaurants in all price ranges. The hotel had recently undergone a renovation and parts of it still had a somewhat older feel to them which to me was actually somewhat charming (such as the accessible balcony even though I was way up), but nothing seemed outdated or worn out in any way. The staff was extremely nice and made the stay more enjoyable. I had a rental car while I was there as well and the valet's were always courteous, helpful and quick no matter when I arrived or departed. You can drive to just about anything you are interested in very quickly from this location and it is easy to get in and out except during rush hour when the H-1 turns into a virtual parking lot.

The Ilikai is a little old and tired however the rooms are very clean and still in good condition. We had a 2 bedroom suite and it was a great size. Really good value. Beds very comfortable and everything very clean and tidy. The view on the ocean side is amazing.The front desk service staff were a little grumpy and unfriendly but were helpful. Concierge staff info very helpful and knowledgeable.

We stayed in a renovated condo, so I can't speak for all the units; however ours was beautiful and had amazing views. The location was awesome and conveniently located to everything, no need for a car. Within minutes you can be at the Ala Moana Mall which was huge, great bars and restaurants around, and ABC stores. Would stay again.

I spent a week at this beautiful hotel. The rooms are twice the size of most hotels, two very large closets, sitting area, dining area, microwave, fridge, coffee maker, a king bed that was very comfortable, balcony with table and chairs and the bathroom was to die for!! The first half had a large vanity, tub with hand held shower, the second half had a shower and toilet (each half was the size of most upgraded hotel baths). The lobby and connecting walkways were spectacular with granite and teak flooring, beautiful flora and fawna, a bar and grill that was wonderful and enough food on 1 plate for 2 people they are so large and wonderful. The pool is beautiful and you are on the Waikiki beach. Most importantly, the staff went out of their way to accomodate any request and they did it with a smile. I was also able to attend church right in the hotel - an interdenominational service with beautiful music and good minister. This hotel is within walking distance of Red Lobster, the Outback, the largest open air mall and so much more. I hope to return someday and visit all the islands, but you can bet this will be my choice of hotels on Oahu!

I came to Oahu for my wedding and spent two nights in a 2 bedroom suite in the Ilikai with my family before moving to the Hilton Hawaiian Village after the wedding. They are right next to each other, and I will be posting a review for the HHV as well. The Ilikai is definitely more reasonably priced, but the property is somewhat outdated for sure. That's not to say that it isn't clean or well-maintained, which it is both; but it does give off somewhat of a 70's vibe as it is an older property. The rooms were very spacious (even a regular room with two single beds which a couple of my friends were in). Everyone working there was very pleasant, and there were no problems with the service either.The location is fantastic, right on the western edge of Waikiki. The beach is a short walk away, as are a lot of great restaurants (Nobu, Morimoto, Roy's) and shopping (Ala Moana Mall). I don't have any complaints about this hotel and would recommend it to anyone visiting Waikiki. Sure, the HHV was nicer as we stayed in a brand new tower there, but for the value and location, the Ilikai is hard to beat!

We chose to stay in Ilikai Hotel for our HoneyMoon trip to Hawaii. We were there for 2 nights before embarking our cruise ship Pride of America. We took an Interior view room and were upgraded to Ocean View. However they gave us two twin beds instead of one King. A little oversight on their part but then they quickly in 30 mins aggranged another room for us with king bed. Overall its a good hotel for the price they charge.

This place was a joy to walk into after a long trip from Oz. Well appointed, the location is great as it is a short 10 mins by trolley car ti Waikiki and just a few mins walk from a huge shopping centre with Macy's and other dept stores as well as hosts of restaurants. With 1 min walk is Maccas, IHOP and other eateries. Large apartment with kitchen and great view over the mariner. Good value for money and for families just fantastic.

Our stay was very enjoyable and pleasant. No bad surprises. Staff is friendly and helpful. We stayed for eight days in this excellent location close to Waikiki Beach. It's away from the busiest part of the Waikiki and you can walk there in ten minutes or less. The hotel is right next to the Hilton Complex which has a lagoon and nice beach.There is a firework show every Friday at the Hilton and the best spot to view is at the raised promenade walkway, we had seats watching the performance outside the hotel restaurant before the fireworks starts. If you are planning to rent a vehicle to tour around the island, which is an excellent idea, you can park your rental car at the marina just behind the hotel which you can park there for $12 for 10 hours during weekdays and $24 for 10 hours on weekends. I would highly recommend Pearl Harbor for at least half day as there are many attractions there. You can miss the west side of the island as there is not much to see there and the crime rate is higher there also. Be sure to check out Hanauma Bay (http://www.hanauma-bay-hawaii.com/) even if you are not snorkelling, the scenery is out of this world but make sure you get there early as the parking lot fills up really fast and there is no parking on the highway. After the short hike from the beach to the parking lot, you should grab some shaved ice at the concession stand, perfect on a hot day! All in all, we truly enjoyed our stay in Honolulu and the Ilikai and we can't hardly wait to go back there sometime soon.

My wife and I stayed in a condo at the Ilikai Oct 1-8 and it was so much more to our liking than the Grand Waikikian and the Hawaiian Village next door. We walked through each of these on the way to the beach each day and felt sorry for those checking into the other properties. We have stayed at both of the mentioned properties and although they have beautiful grounds, the crowds and price don't come close to the serenity and slow pace of the Ilikai! We were in a condo facing the lagoon and ocean and loved the view each morning and evening. The pool was never crowded and the pool loungers were very comfortable. Didn't eat at the hotel restaurant (never saw more than four people) eating there. We rented a car from budget across the street for one day and it was great to drop the car off and walk across the street back to the Ilikai: LOTS OF EASE staying here...a few blocks from Ala Moana shopping center if you need, close the bus lines (which we used daily and very efficient #8), and a short walk to many good restaurants (Roy's, Charthouse, Eggs & Things etc.) The staff was very friendly and helpful (except one). We commented several times on how quiet the hallways were and how easy it was to stay here. Every evening we walked from the Hawaiian Village next the beach to Ft. Derussy and back at sunset. Very beautiful and may be the best highlight of our trip--other than swimming in the ocean every day. I would highly recommend the Ilikai and suggest you go for a room or condo facing the lagoon.

Surprisingly cheap for a hotel on the Waikiki beach (although parking is valet only, which adds some cost). Hotel on the west edge of Waikiki. The interior is a bit outdated, but the rooms are large and clean. There was an early morning false fire alarm during our stay; I don't know whether that was an anomaly or is a regular occurrence. Staff could be friendlier.

We stayed at the Ilikai in October with our two teenage children. We were really happy with the accomodation. We had an Ocean View apartment and spent lots of time on the balcony just watching the water, boats and surfers! We loved that we were close to the Ala Moana Shopping Centre and still within an easy walk to the heart of Waikiki. We found the Concierge extremely helpful and the kids enjoyed the pool. We ate twice at the Island Bar and Grill within the hotel and found it to be very reasonable and the food was good. We would definitely recommend and stay at the Ilikai again. For the price we thought it was fantastic.

We were looking for a comfortable place to stay for a week.The staff is friendly and kind. If you are looking for a good value and want access to a kitchenette to prepare an easy breakfast and some snacks the Ilikai is a great place. The local bus lines that run to the beach and to shopping are right our front. The Ilikai may not look special from the outside, but the the inside is worth every penny.

Booked through waikikioceanfrontrentals.com - brilliant place to stay. Fully equipped kitchen, clean room, comfy beds, very comfy lanai furniture. Great views of marina and ocean from lanai. Short walk to beaches in either direction including Waikiki Beach. Shorter walk to Ala Moana shopping centre for great shopping. Bar and grill downstairs is great, store across street for food, drinks and souvenirs! Jus awesome place to stay! I will be back!!

Stayed 6 nights at the Ilikai from 9/27/11 to 10/3/11. Had an ocean view room on the 23rd floor (room 2318). Had a good view of the ocean and Hilton Hawaiian Village lagoon directly out from front of balcony (provides a good amount of ocean view, but is cut off by the Ilikai building to the right and the Hilton Hawaiian Village lagoon tower to the left. Can see more ocean view when looking to the left while standing on the balcony (can see part of Diamond Head behind other Hilton Hawaiian Village towers). Room had two queen beds, flat screen TV mounted on wall, chair, desk, drawers. The room was surprisingly large, much larger than I needed. Has a large closet with free room safe (iron, ironing board, and hairdryer located in the closet). Bathroom had separate shower and bathtub. Usual bath toiletries (Aqua Hotel brand) that were replenished every day, and also had coffee maker and coffee/creamer/sugar.Room was clean, a little worn, but completely acceptable. Grout in bathroom could probably be redone, but I found the room to be excellent value for the price paid (I found $128 per night on Blue Hawaii Resorts web page, which was at least $35 per night cheaper than all the regular web travel sites). Travelled with a friend who has a fear of heights (we didn't realize that the hotel rooms are all on the upper floors) so they upgraded her for free to a room on the third floor that had a kitchen. My room wasn't ready at 1pm when we arrived, but my friend's room was available and allowed to check-in early. Room was cleaned every day with no complaints. Free stack of local newspaper everyday located on the table near the elevators.We found the only reasonable option for parking was using the hotel valet. There is other parking lots nearby but not for overnight parking. Valet was $25.oo per day, free in and out. The valet folks were extremely efficient and polite. I didn't eat at the hotel, but my friend had breakfast one day and said it was terrible (cold French toast). Did have bar drinks which were reasonable and good.The hotel is located behind the Hilton Hawaiian Hotel on Ala Moana Boulevard, which is a less crowded area at the end of Waikiki near to Honolulu. I enjoyed not being in the craziness of the middle of Waikiki, yet it was only a 5 minute drive (or 15-20 minute walk). Would definitely stay here again when visiting Waikiki. Make sure you get a map if not familiar with Waikiki, a lot of one-way streets make things a little confusing. Additionally, roadworks were going on infront of the hotel (Ala Moana Blvd) at night which made getting back to the hotel a little slow.Things we did while visiting.1. The USS Arizona Memorial - very nicely done tour, arrived at 7:15 am and got into the 8am short movie and boat to the memorial after - gave the rest of the day to do other things.2. Saw a free concert by the Royal Hawaiian Band on the grounds of the Iolani Palace at noon on Friday (think they have concerts every week at that time). Was very enjoyable, the crowd was older.3. Favorite beach - Waimanolo, was almost deserted with beautiful turquoise water (mid week).4. At at Dukes, the Hula Grill, and Tiki Terrace all in Waikiki and all were good.5. The Dole Plantation on the way to the North Shore - the pineapple ice-cream is delicious, but the hard sell from a lot of the employees in the store was off putting.

Like the previous reviewer we were there in early September and had the same problem with the lifts. We had originally booked a Mountain View room and as we had come from Australia we arrived very early in the morning wondering if our room would be ready. Anyway we needn't have worried as the staff on the desk (and they were all great) upgraded us to an Ocean View room overlooking the marina and beach - really beautiful. The room itself was massive with plenty of draw and closet space. My wife and I found the location just fine, a bit of a walk into Waikiki proper but no big deal and my wife has dodgy knees. The Ala Mona shopping center was only 10 minutes walk as well. The grill at the hotel was fabulous - really nice meals and very friendly, helpful staff. The coffee shop in the hotel did the best coffee I've had anywhere in the US. My only gripes was the there wasn't adequate shade at the pool although this didn't seem to bother the Americans? And also I couldn't connect my Ipad through the hotel WI-FI Network although they did have free Wi-Fi at the excellent coffee shop so again no biggie. That was our 1st visit to Hawaii but it wont be the last. It a lovely place with lovely people. Everything so much cheaper than Australia, makes you realise just how much we get ripped off back home in Sydney.So thank you Ilikai for very nice accommodation and service. We'll definitely be back.

This facility is a bit dated, but you cannot beat the location and price. The beach and strip are a quick 5-10 minute walk. The airport shuttle is only $10 per person. Plus you have easy access to drive over to Hanauma Bay or Lanikai Beach.

we stayed here in early September for 10 nights and had booked condo 1802 through Waikikioceanfrontrentals. As no one was in the condo the night before we were able to come in early which was great for us as we were there about 9am. It t was great to just go straight up to the room without having to check in. Loved having a pin code instead of a key or swipe card.....made it a lot easier when going to the beach......no keys to worry about. The condo was exactly as described and was perfect for us. It was very roomy and the view was spectacular ! The beds were really comfortable although the pillows were pathetic, but as we had 2 double beds there were lots of pillows to choose from. The hotel is lovely, the lobby and the outside areas are extremely well maintained. There was always someone cleaning there.............and the outside gardens and water features were beautiful. We ate in the Bar & Grill once for dinner and twice for lunch and the food was always delicious and the staff super friendly. We didn't use the pool as the beach was just a couple of minutes walk down the walkway. The pool was closed until 8.30am each morning as it was used for laps & rehab and then it was closed at 7.30pm. We found this annoying as there were some nights we would have liked to have a quick swim when we got back after a long hot day out.We found it nice to swim just in front of the Tropics restaurant at the Hilton - less rocky there - the water was so nice.As someone mentioned in an earlier review about the lifts,while we were there at one stage it was down to 2 out of 5 lifts working. Fortunately we were on an upper floor as those on lower floors would have had to wait for ages to get on a lift as they were usually full by the time it got to the 15th floor. About half way through our stay the lifts were fixed and 4 out of 5 were working and we had no dramas from then on. There was a lift to use if you had sand or were wet but the few times we went to use this it was also out of order. We liked being at the quieter end of Waikiki although some nights when were were really tired and had been down to Waikiki for dinner we wished were staying closer instead of having to get the bus back (too tired to walk). The proximity to Ala Moana was fantastic and there were 2 ABC stores really close as well as lots of restaurants. We would definitely stay here again - can't wait to go back!!

Stayed at The Ilikai for two nights 9/24,25. Had not been back to the Islands, certainly not Waikiki, for many years. We chose Ilikai for the location as it was next to the venue we needed to go to for an event. Excellent front desk service as well as super friendly staff all around. The bed was fantastic - great comforter, sheets, pillows. No room service but frig and coffee maker in room and plenty of places to shop for food and dining out nearby. Loved the Top of the I - excellent Tapas menu - they have Happy Hour as well. If you want to go to the beach you absolutely MUST wear water shoes as beach is rocky and in barefeet a potential nightmare. Once in the ocean, great swimming and snorkeling. The Bar and Grill is up to par for eating but slow for breakfast. We were on the 25th floor with "ocean view" which it sortof was. Great view anyway but if you have suicidal tendencies stay away from the balcony. If I had children I would not choose this hotel unless I was on the ground - or close to - floor. I like that it is more of an adult's hotel. Love that it is not in the mix of the hoards and masses of Waikiki. Very peaceful and not noisy at all.

we stayed in a one bedroom unit on the 8th floor booked through www.waikikioceanfrontrentals.com as a private rental.i have to say that this unit was exactly the same as the photos and was spotless and the whole process of booking and getting entry codes for the unit went without a hitch. The location of the Ilikai is great if you want to get out of the hustle and bustle on Waikiki. The trolley bus stopped directly outside the hotel and was only 10 mins to the centre of Waikiki. the room had great views of the Hilton Luau everynight and of the fireworks on a friday nights. the only problem i encountered was the front desk would not cash an Amex travellers cheque as we were in a private rental even though we were spending money at the retaurants and bars.That is the first time in 3 trips to the US that i have been unable to cash a TC, even corner shops accept them. Our tour guide said management had recently changed so maybe they hav'nt got their act quite together. the pool is small but never crowded although the pool attendant was sometimes over zealous with the pool rules, not sure if its the pool for children as i don't think the pool attendant likes too much noise. the Hilton lagoon is probably a better option with kids. the bar/restaurant was nice and the food was good. As we were in a private rental there was no room service but we were able to buy meals at the restaurant and bring them back. there is a supermarket a couple of blocks away but it was quite expensive. There is also an ABC store across the road as well that sold the basics (food).there is also a supermarket at Ala Moana shops althought we didn't get to it but i would imagine it would be cheaper that the smallersupermarket nearer to the ilikai. There was a laundry on our floor and i think from memory was $4.50 to do a wash and then more for the dryer.There were only a few shops in the lobby and a lot of empty storefronts but they were in the process of opening a "market". i would say it is open by now. We were there for 7 nights early september so with the change of management there could be more opening. i would definately stay there again and would privately rent again.

If there were a half point rating system on trip advisor, this hotel would be receiving 3.5 starts for our stay because everyone who worked at this hotel was super friendly. Other than that, this hotel was about average, like a Best Western or Motel 8. My husband and I were on our honeymoon when we stayed at this hotel. We booked our hotel room at the Ilikai through our credit card company because we had points we could use towards our room. We stayed here for three nights in the middle of September on the 23rd floor facing the mountains. I notified the hotel before our trip that this was our honeymoon and we would like a king size bed. When we arrived, we were told that we would be receiving 2 double beds. To us, that really was not acceptable for a honeymoon stay, but we really did not have a choice in the matter. The hotel never gave us the option to upgrade to another, maybe more expensive room. To the hotel's credit, the front desk staff did give the appearance that they were working hard on finding us another room with a king size bed, but we never did receive another room with a king bed during our 3.5 day stay.The hotel is situated at the end or beginning (depending on how you look at it) of the Waikiki hotel strip. For this reason, it is super quiet, which was a nice welcome to Honolulu. The hotel itself is, and I stress, dated! We are by no means Ritz Carleton type people, but come on, it's seriously time for a major renovation. Because the hotel rooms are dated, it gives the appearance that the rooms are not clean i.e. torn carpets, small holes in the walls, dirty grout in the bathroom. It really didn't bother us, but I can see how some people would be offended at a room of this magnitude. Our room was fine for maybe a 2 or 3 star standard hotel room. It was clean, and we did not have any problems during our stay. It included a flat screen tv, refrigerator, microwave, shower and bathtub, and it was quite large. We had plenty of room to spread out.We ate at the pool restaurant, which was average and very expensive for what it is. I made the mistake of purchasing water and a couple of bags of chips at the store in the hotel on the first night we were there....talk about price gauging. $10 for a gallon of water and two small bags of chips. I know Hawaii in general is expensive, but come on! I wish I would have known that there was an ABC store right next to the hotel so I didn't get ripped off.The hotel pool is small and nice enough for a quick dip. Who really needs a pool when the ocean is almost at your door step? By no means is this hotel directly on the beach, but it is within a quick 10 minute walk down a walkway and around the Hilton Lagoon to the beach. The hotel also offers beach and pool towels to use, but whatever you do, do not lose your towel cards because they will charge you $25 a pop if they are lost.We ate at a local coffee shop for breakfast almost every day we were there, and at the sports bar across the street. I would not recommend renting a car unless you plan to travel to more distant parts of Oahu, like the North Shore. It's really not worth it, and the bus system seems to be pretty reliable. We walked everywhere, and it was a nice way to really see the sights.

This hotel lived upto every expectation we had. Gorgeous view over the Hilton Lagoon and out to Diamond Head and the ocean. The bathroom was amazingly roomy which was something we wanted and swayed us to pick this as our accommodation. The room overall was very luxurious and a nice place to come back to after being out on tours or at the beach. Loved the little coffee shop in the hotel, great cappucinos, and great to find a coffee shop that serves different types of coffees not some black stuff thats been sitting brewing in a pot all day. The bar/restaurant in the hotel lobby was a great find and so convenient for any meals, particularly early morning breakfasts before heading off on tours. The hotel is in a good location to shops, the main beaches and having the trolley bus stop in front was very handy. The reruns of Hawaii Five-0 in the lobby were a brilliant touch. Very glad we stayed here.

My wife grew up in Kaimuki. We have been going to HI for many years and have many friends that live in Honolulu. The Ilikai is a fixture in Waikiki, but has still maintained its Aloha in the face of an overflow of tourists. We paid a little extra for an ocean view with sunset; it was worth every penny. Large rooms (compared to the Royal Hawaiian and Surfrider) at a fraction of the cost make this a great bargain. For us (we are in our 60s) we could easily walk to some of the best restaurants in Waikiki (Roys, House without a Key, etc.) and the nearby beaches. Our favorite was a walk to Ala Moana Shopping center to pick up a bento from Shirokiya and head over to the Ala Moana Park for a picnic and swimming.

Just returned from our 3 day stay at the Ilikai. Rooms are large with a large bathroom with separate toilet area with its own shower. Beds are comfortable and 4 people did not feel crowded. The hotel is very clean and staff go out of their way to make your stay a pleasant one. Part of the hotel is time share, but no one bothered us there. One person mentioned it to our friend and then let it drop..no pushiness. The highest floors are the hotel rooms and that was great! There is a magnificent restaurant on the highest floor. The roof is the place where the opening scene of the original Hawaii Five-0 was filmed. We were on the opposite side from the sunset but the sunrise over Diamond Head is lovely as well. We actually were able to watch a luau on the roof of the building next door and to hear the music from it..not too loud..just pleasant. Sat on balcony and watched the surfers morning and evening. Great little coffee shop downstairs with very friendly staff! Convenience store in lobby as well. Loved the balcony to our room.Free internet was a bonus!! Valet parking was quick and convenient with in and out privileges.-I would not hesitate to recommend this property to friends and clients.For those on a bit of a food budget...McDonalds and IHop and The Ala Moana great Shopping Mall with a food court (try the Japanese...it is fantastic!) are a very short walk away. 2 ABC stores within a block (anyone who has been to Hawaii knows about these convenience stores.)Transportation to the main Waikiki beach is frequent and not expensive but walking is very easy.We will definitely return to the Ilikai at our first opportunity!Thank you to the front desk staff who were so friendly and helpful at all times.

We rented a 1 bdrm condo privately thru VRBO.com, and really loved this building. It is in a good location at the end of the sandy beach, great for people who like to walk. The building has great views and is very well built, you cannot hear your neighbors, unless they are being noisy out on their balconies. Our condo was next to the elevators,(#1528) but only rarely could we hear a faint ding of the elevator reaching our floor. Although this condo had not been updated (except for new carpet) it was very clean, no bugs, cool old retro stove in an aqua color, but otherwise new appliances, fully stocked kitchen, linens, beach towels,soaps, cleaners, we did not want for anything! Bed was firm but comfy, tons of pillows to choose from, great water pressure in the shower, just great for 2 people who dont spend all day indoors. We could walk to foodland at the ala moana shopping center for groceries(or you could take one of the many buses). The balcony was nice to sit on in the afternoon, but it was not quiet like a beachfront condo in maui, you could not hear the waves laping at the shore, mostly air conditioners, generators from the hilton hawaiian village, but that is what you get in Waikiki, there are no condos that close to the waves. Sure you could pay much more at an expensive hotel and get closer to the waves, but for $110 a night you cannot beat the Ilikai. ( We did consider renting a condo at the waikiki shore, but are glad we choose not to, as there is not much of a beach in front of that skinny little building, and the lanais either face another building or a pathway to the beach. That area was just too busy for us) We walked there many times for dinner and were glad to walk back to our quiet area at the Ilikai.We saw the fabulous firework show from our lanai on Friday night, and walked thru the Hilton Hawaiian village, on our way out every night, the Tropics bar/restaurant there had great bands at happy hour and sunset, also the best mai tai's. We like to walk, so the walk to the beach was 5 to 10 mins depending on what piece of the beach appealed to us, we looked for the sandiest entrance to the water, cause there is rocks and coral just in front of the logoon side of the hilton (bring water shoes, cause that is a nice beach otherwise, water was very warm there) If you sit in front of the Hale Loa hotel the beach is fine for bare feet. We walked to Diamond head and hiked up the hill one morning, it took about an hour to get there and another 50 mins to get up and down, but after 8:30 Am that climb gets really busy, with people who are not used to hiking or doing hundreds of stairs so it could take much longer to get up and down later in the day. (there is no passing people on the stairs, too narrow)Best restaurants, Roys, Lulu's, Hula grill for dinner, Dukes & Tropics for happy hour. Don't bother with the shorebird, buffets are overpriced for what you get and cooking your own meat at dinner is a novelty, the steak was not good quality, and you could get one done for you at the same price else where.

The hotel is beautifully decorated and landscaped, the rooms are lovely, especially the ones with sunset views, even the in-house beach bar was a decent place to eat lunch.. My only disappointment was how difficult it was to access the beach from the hotel. There is a large parking lot for the marina in the back of the property and it is fenced for a very long stretch. The Hilton Hawaiian Village next door doesn't make it easy to get through their property, so you end up schlepping around a long ways. We did an Aqua Snooze n Cruze (sic) package and got the room, rental car and free parking -- and since parking is $20 a day, that was a great deal. The hotel is at the far western end of Waikiki, but it is close to Ala Moana Center if you are a shopping freak.

The features that greeted us in the hotel as we entered such as the beautiful flower arrangements etc looked superb, the friendliness of the staff made us feel very welcomed. We saw staff continually cleaning, polishing, vacuuming, sweeping every day keeping the hoel and surrounding areas immaculate. Our condo was a great, everything we needed was there, the bed was very comfortable, the kitchen more than adequate and the view from our room magnificent. In all our stay was wonderful and we look forward to returning some time soon.

Rented one of the vacation condos available at the Ilikai for a week. Hotel and condo properties are exteremely well maintained. Our condo had a fabulous view, very nice accomodations, comfortable furniture and beds, and the unit was fully equiped. Even had beach chairs and mats etc for our use. The only problem we encountered was slow elevators. At any given time only 3 of the 6 elevators were working and the place is VERY busy - lots of people coming and going - so during the morning hours or early evening hours you could wait for 15 to 20 minutes before there would be room for us in one of the elevators. Sometimes it was better to catch one going up - just to go down.The Ilikai is located at the top end of Waikiki Beach and it makes it close to many restuarants small shops (like the ABC Stores) and the Ala Moana shoping Center. It is also right on the main bus lines and tour bus stops. This made it extremely easy to get anywhere we wanted to go. All the bus drivers were very helpful if you let them know where you were trying to go.It was a great place to stay - and we plan on going agin next year!

The condo is very nice. But, the property management of the Ilikai makes this place not kid friendly at all. If you have just the slightest bit of sand on your feet, you will be reprimanded by security. Oh, and if you want to swim with your kids in the pool, there is no jumping, if you want to play in the pool, they call it horseplay. When you ask for management, you get security officers. We made reservations to stay for 7 days, but left after two as my family and I felt as though we were staying in a prison. When I notified the owner that we made arrangements to move to a place where we could actually have some fun (this was a vacation after all), the owner apologized for the terrible experience. I did ask the owner if she would consider refunding the money (I do acknowledge the reservation was non-refundable) for the time we did not stay, and her response was I am sorry, I can not refund your money, I can not rent the place out now... Very disappointing, after she was very helpful in recommending places to eat, beaches to visit, ect. It is probably a great place for people on business, or perhaps just couples, but NOT if you are bringing your children...

I travelled to Oahu by myself. I was origianally planning on staying long term at a condo (one month lease) but plans changed. The condo I was looking at to rent was at the Ilikai. I later discovered there was also a hotel at this location, and the price to stay on the beach in Waikiki was fantastic. I was so happy I stayed here.My original budget allowed me to stay here (treat myself to room with ocean view) and the sapend the second half of my vacation at a less expensive hotel a couple blocks away from the ocean. NOTE: this was bad judgemnet on my part; I should have stayed at the Ilikai the whole time!The hotel itself looked dated from the outside. The lobby was open and airy. I was pleasantly surprsied at my room... It was one of the largest rooms I've stayed in at a hotel. The furnishings were new, and the room was clean. There was a tiny bar fridge. My room had an awesome view (ocean, Hilton Hawaiian Village and the Lagoon). I often visited the Hilton Hawaiian Village next door (which is awesome and goes on forever). The price for this hotel was very competitive.As a solo traveller, I felt safe at this hotel, but not safe walking on the street out front of this hotel at night. I still did go ut alone though, and had no problems.The location was perfect for me... There's a hugh resort next door, awesome views of the lagoon and marina, it's the start of Waikiki beach (so it's not incredibly crowded here), you can catch the city buses out front that take you over the whole island, there was a McDonalds and popular chicken wing place across the road (as well as car rental).The clientele seemed to mostly seniors (and re-occurring) guests here. I'm in my 30s, but was ok with that. I had no troubles.The restaurant up top has fantastic views and amazing prices for an italian meal if you can get there during happy hour.Also, there was a laundry facilty and pop machine on my floor for reasonable prices.This building is a combo of a hotel, time share and condo.

The Ilikai Hotel & Suites was great this trip August 29th to September 13th. A wonderful 15 day stay. The staff remembered us and treated us great. The Ilikai Bar and Grill had excellent food and lots of it. The Mt Kaala Coffee Shop was a great change. The room had a great view of the lagoon and ocean. It was a a clean and comfortable 500 square foot kitchen unit. It gave us a spectacular view of the fireworks shows on Friday nights. Looking forward to seeing the new stores on the main level the next time we visit.

Aside from the fact that less than 50% of the lifts were working at any one time, which made traveling to and from the 19th floor a chore, we realty enjoyed our stay. Quaint apartment with everything you need for a comfy stay. Friendly hotel staff too. Would stay again.

Stayed for there nights at the SVC timesheet that we traded with RCI. Very nice studio with full kitchen. Granite counters. Upgraded bathroom with beautiful file. Has ac. Nice oceanview from balcony. Could see luau at Hilton Hawaiian Village from our room. Close to water. Nice grounds and lobby. Extremely nice staff throughout. Timeshare staff were extremely helpful and nice....much different than past experiences with timeshare trades. Short 2 min walk to Waikiki. Within walking distance of Ala Moana Center. One block from tons of Waikiki shopping. Great beaches and surfing.

We arrived in Honolulu on August 29, 2011 for 10-day vacation. We arranged airport pick up with Speedi-Shuttle and they were waiting for us with leis when we came out of the airport. While driving us to our hotel, our driver gave us a guided tour pointing out spots of interest. When we arrived at Ilikai Hotel in Waikiki we were told that we had been upgraded from a regular room to a room with a kitchen and sitting area. This was great as we had a full size fridge and we could put snacks and drinks in our room. We had an ocean view room on the 18th floor overlooking the Hilton Hawaiian Village and we shared the lagoon. Every Friday night the Hilton puts on a fireworks display from the lagoon. We had a great view of the fireworks from our balcony. They were spectacular. Most mornings we ate breakfast in our room. The hotel is at the edge of Waikiki Beach but yet very close to shopping, restaurants and many touris attractions. We did not rent a car as the bus system in Waikiki is so good. There are also trolleys that you can catch that will take you to so many places. Make sure that you visit Hilo Hatties factor store. Lots of really good quality clothing and the prices are very reasonable. We spend one entire day at the Polynesian Cultural Centre. This was great as we got to see many of the polynesian cultures that make up the Hawaiian Islands. Afterwards we attended a luau and saw the evening show "Ha: Breath of Life". This was an excellant show. All in all it was a great vacation and I would definitely recommend the Ilikai Hotel as a great place to stay while in Honolulu.

My husband and I were here for business and this was the hotel for the meetings. Our room was near the top--we had a city view but splendid nonetheless. Our room was so big compared to the last Waikiki hotel we stayed at. The staff was very helpful and were quick to solve problems like closet doors off track. Enough light to read before bed--comfortable beds, good water pressure--everything you would want for a comfortable stay. It is an older property, but the location was so good--within walking distance of whatever you'd want to do--the mall, the beach and everything in between. Don't hesitate to give it a try.

Enjoyed our stay at the Ilikai condo. We had a great condo in a great location, with beautiful views at a good price. The hotel is close to many restaurants and stores and every possible mode of transportation stops at the front door. Great beaches are also nearby. We would highly recommend this hotel/condos if a fair price can be negotiated. Condos $125-$150 seem to be much more reasonable than most hotel rooms in the area on the water. This is an older property but has been updated. Be selective, some condos have been updated some not. Stay high and harbor facing. Food store Food Pantry is best place to shop. You can walk to all of Waikiki from here, don't need a car. The top of the hotel is in the opening scene of Hawaii-50, old and new series. Highly recommend this property if you find an appropriate condo online. We hope to be back every year.

Don't judge a book by its cover! Needed a last minute place to stay for a wedding, but spent hours & hours reading hotel reviews. Decided on Ilikai & got an excellent deal by booking hotel with flight. Not impressed when viewed from the shuttle, but WOW, wonderful hotel inside! Lobby is BEAUTIFUL, room was clean, quiet, comfy & pleasant to be in. (Rec'd free upgrade upon check-in without asking.) Shower was adequate, but no full size tub, so don't expect to do any soaking. All staff was friendly. Located within decent walking distance to shopping, all types of restaurants & of course the beach. Nice view on 'Mountain' side. Hadn't reserved a car ahead of time, so concierge booked one for me. More expensive than if I had included it in the package, but still cheaper than walking into the rental co myself. Wonderful experience. Will stay there again & highly recommend.

We stayed on the 7th floor in one onf the timeshare units owned by Shell Vacation Club.It is a suite-like studio, but was big and setup in such a way we didnt miss the lack of a private seating area for watchng tv etc. Good size marble countered kitchen with full cooking ability was a plus. We did eat out a few times, tho... and one of them actually used a Groupon I had gleaned for Honolulu while still at home. (the other HI islands are not well represented on Groupon). Everything was close by,..and the bus service was fantastic.. stopping right outside the door.We had booked return to airport with Richards transportation... but when they failed to arrive, the doorman called another (even CHEAPER) van service..and we both went for less than $15.Hotel itself has a nice pool and a raised area in the back where you can overlook the Marina. It is right next door to the Massive Hilton Hawaiian Village and its myriad of shoppes and restaurants, There is a very nice restaurant at the top of Ilikai. I think it has an Italian name like "Robertos" or something like that,, had just missed a groupon for $20 off. We didnt attend the Fri 5:30 hula session up there as we were on the circle tour of Oahu. We had a strange experience one night at appx 3am the fire alarm went off,, we endured ear-splitting screeching, then it would stop, then we heard staff talking back and forth on their devices.. then it would start screeching again.. then finally we were told to stay in the rooms it was a situation on the lower floor. Went back to try to sleep again.. it happened again.. were told the sprinkler system on one floor had gone off; not to worry--no fire. At the desk next day my husband complained about it, they were nice enough to tell us some young guest had decided to hang their clothes from one of the sprinklers, and water ruined several rooms all in that area. We came back to our rm that evening, and special delivery of a nice box of goodies from Hawaiian Cookie Co. was waiting for us with an apologetic note.. I said before, this was a timeshare unit we occupied, there were privately owned condos all along hit or miss on our floor, and also hotel rooms. We heard that the actor last name Kim lives in the building...It is incidentally the bldg. that was immortalized in the orig,.Miami 5-0 with Jack Lord out standing on the rooftop balcony. We had a balcony too, and it overlooked Ala Moana Blvd... and the edge of the Hawaiian Village looking down towards the Waikiki Beach main area. I highly recommend it..

It's a great place to stay. Location is perfect, if you have a car. Rooms are clean. If you're looking for a luxurious five star place this isn't the place for you. But it's perfect for me because it's clean and comfortable! The only down fall about this hotel is the extremely pricey valet parking.

Ilikai Condo # 1304 is awesome. The view is ideal from the lanai. You can see the marina & ocean. Quiet yet still in the middle of all the activities Oahu offers. The amenities are wonderful~complete kitchen set-up, plus laundry supplies for the washer & dryer right down the hall. It is perfect! We loved our stay & will be back again :)

Ilikai is down to earth and pleasant, and conveniently located at the end of Waikiki Beach, not on the beach, you have to walk about 5 minutes to get there. Also close to Ala Moana Shopping Center, about a 10 minute walk. But the price this time (August 2011) was $170/night, compared with about $110/night just 18 months ago (in December 2009). That is getting pricey, so I'll look at other hotels on my next trip. Air conditioner was a bit noisy. Otherwise, great.

The condo was well equipped with a great view of the lagoon and beach. The furniture is very comfortable, especially the bed, and the kitchen is modern and has everything you need. The beach gear was also a plus. It's a 5 minute walk to the beach and lagoon and is very close to shops, and there are plenty of great eating options nearby.There's a lot of different parking options but we went with the hotel valet which was kind of steep, but well worth every penny...very convenient at the end of a long evening or adventure filled day.My only suggestion would be to have another mirror somewhere outside of the bathroom. We were there for a friend's wedding so getting ready with 1 mirror was tough, but the bathroom is very roomy so it worked out well anyway. We had some friends over 1 evening and they were impressed with the condo too.Communication with the owner was easy and she made sure that we had everything we needed for our stay. I would definitely stay there again!

We just rented a condo in this building for ten days. I did some involved research before going and everything was pretty bang on. The condo itself was quite lovely inside after being renovated the last year or so. The stainless steel kitchen and granite tops were quite ample and I did cook quite a lot of our meals there with no problem. It was nice to cook with the ocean view. The smoke alarm would go off but there is a button on there to 'push to hush'! The bathroom was fine except that we had a unit (2124) that had a japanese soaking tub...not the easiest thing to get in and out of and it didn't really drain that well. The beds were comfortable but just a double size. The living area a hit with my 11 year old boy who liked to have his time there while we sat on the lanai most of the time. At first I was scared of the high height but I knew this at the time of booking and I just wanted to have the views. That I was not disappointed on as the views were amazing - the ocean, the lagoon, towards Diamond Head. The luxury tower of the Hilton Hawaiian Village Hotel was right opposite us and we would drink our wine just staring at it and wondering who could afford the penthouses on top! I actually felt sorry for the people in them as their view was the Ilikai which to be honest looks like an old rundown block of flats in my native UK.The view of their pools was also great and a nightly luau was our entertainment. The walk right into Waikiki was OK but if you're doing it everyday you might want to wear runners. Buy your groceries at Foodland which is walkable to the Ala Moana Mall on the NW corner, 2nd level. Cab back cost $10 with tip. Book any trips with Summer Sells, the concierge at the Ilikai (that's acutally her name) she was very informative and her prices came out cheaper than when I looked online. We ate at the bar and grill only once. Unfortunately it was about 9:30pm at night, the tables were dark and my son ordered a cheeseburger. It wasn't until the last few bites that I noticed it was still pink. They took it back and said it was medium rare. I was furious at myself for not checking at first. The waiter said he would not charge us for it but with a laugh said he couldn't pay for the hospital bill. That put us off for the rest of the holiday but fortunately my son did not get sick. Overall a very affordable and comfortable place to stay. No problems with the private rental of codes to get in and payment.

A nice reasonably priced hotel that includes kitchen units and a great city or ocean view. Staff is very friendly and accommodating. There is a wheelchair accessible room and lots of elevators. No restaurant on site however. All units have a nice large balcony area. Washing machines are also available. Parking available for extra fee. Located just on the outskirts of Waikiki, you can avoid the noise and traffic. Within walking distance of Ala Moana Park and Shopping Center. Located next door to the Hilton so you can watch the fireworks display every Friday night!

We (family of 4, kids are 13 &11) stayed in condo 2032 (rented from VRBO) for 1 week in July at the beginning of our 4 week trip to Hawaii. The condo is exactly as pictured and the view is beautiful. Having a kitchen was a huge benefit. The location was perfect for us, with a very nice walk down the beach to the heart of Waikiki for shopping or dining. Ala Moana Centre is just a 10 min walk the other way, with everything you need, and there is an ABC store right across the street from the Ilikai. The Hilton Lagoon was great for the kids and they loved renting the stand up paddle boards. The beach is rocky, so water shoes are a good idea for the ocean, but otherwise, the Ilikai and Waikiki were a perfect fit for us. The Bar and Grill on the main level past the lobby had very good food. We ate there for breakfast and dinner, all good. Honolulu is a great city with lots to see and do. I recommend hiking Diamond Head, taking in all the sites and museums at the Pearl Harbor site, and definitely take a day and spend it on the North Shore! We stopped at Shark's Cove, Waimea Valley where you can swim under the falls, and absolutely go to Macky's shrimp truck for lunch while in Hale'iwa town! It parks beside the 7-11 on the edge of town--the best garlic shrimp around! (this was a tip by a local and we were SO glad we had lunch there!) Then grab a Shave Ice at Matsumto right on the main road in town. Enjoy Sam's condo and the area, it was a blast for us and we wouldn't hesitate to stay at the Ilikai again.

We stayed at the Ilikai via a private vacation rental company (not directly through the Ilikai) so this review will not speak so much to the room itself (which was just perfect!).From the outside, the hotel doesn't look very appealing. It probably looks like one of the more dated hotels actually, but once inside, it is well maintained and clean. Definitely one of the those don't judge a book by its cover situations. The location of the hotel was perfect. It's a good 10-15 walk into the bustling parts of Waikiki but good for those looking for a quieter environment, especially at night. The last time I visited Honolulu, we stayed in the heart of Waikiki where the noise of buses, cars, tourists, etc never seemed to let up. Coffee, McDonald's, ABC store and a diner of sorts are in the immediate vicinity of the hotel as well as other smaller shops.The beach and the Hilton lagoon are almost directly behind the hotel. The beach is a little rocky and the lagoon water always colder than the beach (not good for wimpy people like me), so if you're looking to spend time at a nice beach, plan on driving somewhere else. The lagoon is a good option for people traveling with small kids though.The pool is a decent size and pretty well maintained. The only drawback is you can't consume any outside food or drink. The other drawback of the Ilikai is the parking situation. You can only park there using their valet service which is $22/day and does not include gratuity. There is a public lot immediately behind the hotel but you pay based on the time you will be parked (you can pay to park for 10 hours but there are no in and out privileges). If you're visiting Honolulu for the first time, you probably don't need a car as all the things you would want to do/see are within walking distance or can reach easily by bus. Overall, I had a great stay at the Ilikai and would definitely return...just wish they'd do something about the parking...it's a total rip off.

I booked the Ilikai condo through waikikioceanfrontrentals.com and the process was very smooth. However, please be aware that they charged me an international fee because their office or invoice processing center was located in Canada. I had to dispute that charge and they finally credit me the charge. I booked a 2 bedroom corner unit condo on the 15th floor facing the busy street. I love the fact that is a corner unit because it gave me a glimpse of the marina. I originally was concerned about the noise from the street but it turned out ok. The condo was very spacious with approximately 1300 square feet. One bedroom had AC and the other didn't but it was sufficient because we left the door opened so the AC from the dining room area flowed in. Overall the condo was sufficiently equipped and clean. I may consider coming back to Ilikai on my next trip.

I stayed here with my teen son in early June 2011. I struggle price-wise to find a balance between beach front and great hotel amenities to interest him. We almost hit the mark with the Ilikai.Rooms at the I' are very comfy. Nothing new or outstanding about them. We had a large, 25th floor room. So large that other seating could easily have fit in the room and would have been welcomed. Although the bathroom had some appearance of remodeling, it stopped at the tub/shower area. If your kids are active, the I' Hotel might not be for you. The pool was a little disappointing and as our room looked out over the far end of the famed (insert hotel name) Hawaiian Villiage, my son had a lot of 'pool' envy. I later found out that the pool used to be the kiddie pool before the Ilikai gave over some property to a newer boutique hotel. I know several military families awaiting housing set up camp in the I' Hotel, so they might want to work on some reciprocity with one of the nearby properties (just a thought).The staff of the hotel was good. The front desk was always friendly and helpful. The concierge is also very helpful. Location was excellent for me. I'd read other reviews about how noisy Waikiki properties were. The I' Hotel is at the far western edge of Waikiki, making it more of a "Honolulu" property. You can sun out in front of other properties or at the lagoon. There's a bus line right out front. If you want to get your exercise, Waikiki and Ala Moana are within walking distance. The hotel provides regular sized beach towels (true 'beach' not plain towels). There's a small, nicely equipped gym. Lots of elevators, so no long wait, plus a 'swimmers'' elevator. Laundry facilities on (I think) every floor.If you're staying for longer than a week, especially with kids, I highly recommend bringing an extra bag with non-perishable staples like cereal, pop tarts, packaged snacks, pretzels (chips might get crushed), canned soups, popcorn, juice boxes, (shelf) milk, plastic utensils; I' Hotel has microwaves and small fridges in rooms. I was fortunate not to have to pay for my bags, but even with the bag charge, you'll save money (you might want to box it up instead of a bag or nestle the empty bag in a larger one for the return flight).If you get the "upgrade at reservation for small fee" option, take it. We upgraded at check in to an ocean view, 25th floor room, which was great. If you do get a room overlooking the lagoon, order pizza in on Friday (or go for a late dinner) as this is where the fireworks are set off.Overall, I had a good experience and stay at the Ilikai.
Stayed on the 25th floor facing the Mariner. Very quiet, large rooms, clean with nice linen. Big flat screen TV. Excellent location. Just an all round lovely hotel!

Stayed for three nights recently and were happy with our stay. Hotel is a bit worn around the edges but staff were friendly and we had a lovely view from our double double room. We had a car and used the (paid) valet parking. Didn't use any hotel dining but theres a fantastic diner across the road and up a bit and the Ala Moana centre is within walking distance. Kids were happy enough with the pool and we encountered the "firm" pool attendant mentioned in other reviews but had no issues. Would stay here again, especially once the kids discovered the Brady bunch stayed here too!

The condo is well looked after and very clean. We loved the location - less than 10 minutes walk to Ala Moana Shopping Centre and the main Waikiki strip/restaurants. Trolley and bus stops right outside the door. Great pool for the kids and the lagoon and beach are very close by. Lots of fun toys for them to take to the beach. King bed extremely comfortable. Ample storage. Kitchen well equipped (would be good to have an electric jug/kettle). Great to have use of wireless internet and free local calls. We were treated to a hula show on the roof of the hotel next door almost everynight as well which was great! The only challenge for us was that our children are young and easily woken so once they were in bed we needed to be very quiet and minimise the lighting as there was only a thin sliding door between the bedroom and the rest of the apartment. The apartment isn't newly renovated but this doesn't matter. It is light and bright and has everything you need. Nice view of the water off to the right. A great way to wake up each day! Great to have the kitchen facilities particularly with children. Our preferred grocery shop was The Pantry about 10 mins walk away. Fresh food and salads and some brands from home. We also tried Foodland (a small Woolies or IGA in Oz) but didn't think it was as good. Don Quiyote is also meant to be great but we didn't manage to get there. We would stay in the apartment again if it was the two of us. A great affordable option with all the added features you don't get in a hotel room. Lastly the owners were lovely and great to deal with - they responded to questions very quickly and provided lots of good advice. Thank you Sue and Terry for a great holiday! We loved it.

This property, 1304 Ilikai, is in a perfect location to what is going on in Waikiki...and a bit out of the hustle & bustle of the deep Waikiki street scene with tons of people. Easy to get to Ala Moana for shopping, entire Honolulu bus system, food (the Food Pantry is even closer and there are many restaurants closer.) One neighbor walks to the Honolulu Zoo DAILY! along the beach which has a fantastic view of Diamond Head (looking east). Looking west is the coast and Ala Moana Beach Park and Magic Island and the yacht harbor..where the Trans-Pac boats tied up in July..amazing! This spot is in the thick of it view wise and convenience wise, but quite and incredibly peaceful at the same time.

We were visitors from Australia , stayed two times late June and mid July found accomodation first class, front desk staff very informative and helpful. Rooms were very clean and comfortable , would definitely recommend to any Aussies visiting Honolulu..Location within walking distance of Waikiki beach and many attractions--Well done Ilikai ....
Our family of 3 stayed in a privately owned condo which was very nice. The hotels has a lot of facilities and the food in the Bar & Grill is great.

I stayed at the Ilikai last year and it had a really good time. The hotel was clean, the staff were friendly. The view from the penthouse bar of sunset was fantastic. It was a two minute walk out the backdoor to the ocean. There are restaurants all over the place nearby. My room was great. It was an efficiency with a balcony that had ocean views. I would go back there again tomorrow.
user_name:
tek1025
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Our room was beautiful! It was spacious and elegant, as well as impeccably clean. We brought 4 teenagers with us so we were glad the sleeping arrangements allowed us (my husband and I) to have privacy in our own bedroom on the opposite side of the suite. Everyone slept comfortably and the little kitchen allowed us to enjoy some meals in our room, which was convenient at times throughout our vacation. The view from the room was twofold -- off the master bedroom there was a balcony that afforded us a beautiful city view towards Diamond Head. Then off the other bedroom there was another balcony that had an ocean view (see picture). We enjoyed our coffee every morning on the balcony watching the sun come up to another beautiful day in Hawaii!The staff was very friendly and helpful. We received complete directions to all the places we wanted to see. The pool area was inviting, as were the outdoor areas near the restaurant facing the ocean. We participated in a mini-luau hosted by the hotel which was not only affordable, but the food was great and the music and dancing was really special!The hotel design harkens back to another time (the 70s) but has been completely updated and given all the modern conveniences -- the best of both worlds.I will come back to this hotel again for sure (next time for a romantic getaway with my husband). I will recommend the Ilikai Hotel to anyone interested in a fantastic Hawaiian experience with comfort, elegance and value.

We were a bit unsure about the hotel at first. It looks quite aged from the outside, but clearly a lot of time has been spent remodelling. We had trouble checking in as our room was not ready but was upgraded to compensate for the wait. Beautiful 24th floor room looking over the lagoon with an amazing view of the Friday fireworks. Location was good, front desk were very helpful in finding nice places to eat for a reasonable price. Overall, very impressed.

Stayed two nites, our first time at the hotel. Have visited Honolulu many, many times in the past. We got an upgrade to ocean view at no extra cost, real nice, great sunset. Large bedroom and nice balcony, we had the 24th flr. Fitness center is ok, a couple of the equip could use an upgrade but the rest were adequate, the thread mills had individual TV monitors, but you need to bring your own ear buds or earphones. Convenient nearby restaurants, like the Coffee House, my long time favorite.

We have stayed at the Ilikai for the past three summers, renting different condo's. We love the Ilikai's location, convenience and the fact that the new owners have been remodeling and upgrading the facility since last year. We are both Hawaii Five-O fans from back in the day of Jack Lord, so it is like staying at an historical place. People who worked valet were very helpful and accommodating. The businesses located on the lobby floor were nice to have, especially the coffee house. I would highly recommend the Ilikai to anyone and everyone.

Stayed there recently on our first trip to Honolulu. We picked the Ilikai based on the generally good reviews on Tripadvisor and weren't disappointed. We chose an ocean view room and we had a magnificant view of Diamondhead and the Pacific from our lanai. Also, every night there was an unobstructed view of a Luau directly below us and fireworks shows several nights during our stay. The front desk and concierge were very courteous and helpful as well. The only complaints that I had, and I agree they are nit picky was the water pressure for shower was very low, although I guess that's to be expected on the 24th floor and the internet service wasn't wireless, so I was confined to surf from the desk. Other than those 2 minor details, the stay was excellent. We would highly recommend that if you've got a trip planned for Honolulu, do as we did and "book 'em Danno" at the Ilikai!

The Ilikai was amazing. The front of the building does not look like much when compared to the resort beside it, but once you get inside the foyer that all changes. The lobby is beautiful and open with a cool breeze blowing through. There is a couple of small shops and a coffee shop right as you walk in. Through the lobby is a "deck" overlooking the harbor with an outside bar. The pool a basic hotel pool, but it was clean and well stocked with towels and chairs. The staff was amazing throughout our stay - always happy to answer our many questions.Now the room - Our room was amazing. It was huge, open, and airy. The entire outside wall opened with sliding glass doors onto a nice size patio overlooking the harbour and the historic Duke Paoa Kahanamoku Lagoon. The sheets and comfortor were so clean and soft that we slept like babies all night long. Definitely one of the best rooms we have ever stayed in.

We stay at the Ilikai Hotel because they often have specials on rates (usually linked to the original TV show: "Hawaii Five-O"). One can get a room with a kitchen if traveling with family, which is always helpful. It is also within walking distance to the Ala Moana Shopping Center since it is on that side of Waikiki. It is also right on the beach next to a yacht harbor, so takes 2-3 minutes to walk from one's room to the beach (it is located next to the Hilton Village, so if facing that side of the beach, at night one can hear the Hilton Luau festivities). Across the street are a McDonald's and Aloha Sushi (plus Indian Restaurant and a coffee shop, ABC Store), making it convenient for a quick, cheap bite to eat when not in the mood for a full-blown sit-down meal. The rooms are very big. Some come with a shower and a tub, plus an additional shower, and some only with a shower (which is slightly dark due to inadequate lighting).We have stayed there four times and have always had polite and courteous service. Each time the check-in staff did their best to provide us with a room that had a lovely ocean view. Once, when it was booked solid, we had a view of the city, but we didn't spend much time in the room.They have a LAN line in the room to connect to a computer, but no free wifi (one can access that in the lobby by requesting a password), so that is one inconvenience.

We booked under the "Government TLA" discount, which is described on the website as: "We understand the importance of making the most of your government per diem for official travel at our honolulu hotel. With our Government/TLA program, get free daily parking worth $22 a day. Valid for stays through December 31, 2011. Valid government ID required upon check in or rate subject to change." So, traveling on government business with ID and travel order gets this discount, no? Upon check-in, we were told TLA means govt or military employees temporarily relocated and awaiting permanent housing.... NO mention of this on website and we had already rented a car, counting on the free parking. Took quite a bit of persuading but finally convinced them that their website was misleading at best, and got the discount. Sandra was very helpful in working this out for us, so thanks to her.In general, we really like the hotel, rooms are big, and our kitchen room made it easy to save money on meals. Location is great, we were able to choose our room with the help of "Room 77" iPhone app, which lets you see the view from the room you're assigned. We took a sunset view of the harbor (room #2235 - awesome view!) and were really happy with it. The cleaning staff is great, very accommodating. Bedding is extremely comfortable, clean, lots of pillows. Our room had a sofa, chair, desk w/chair, and full kitchen, including a full-size fridge, oven, microwave. Bathroom was roomy, with no tub but a large shower and good water pressure.Did not go to the rooftop restaurant, too pricey. The courtyard restaurant is so-so, slow service and not a big menu, but there are so many other places to eat right in the area - including the Hilton Hawaiian Village and McD's and Subway right across the street.The pool desperately needs updating, enlarging, or something, at least give us a view of the ocean while we swim in the pool. The internet situation is ridiculous, their business center charges a minimum of $5.50 for 20 minutes on their computer - even if all you need to do is print out your boarding pass! Fortunately, the Hilton (right next door) has several locations where even non-guests can confirm their flight and print a boarding pass for free!The Ilikai has a great history and so much potential to be a phenomenal hotel, but the new owners (Aqua) need to up their game, do some renovations, improve food, pool and internet situation. This was our second stay here, the first being when Marriott owned it, and it was a more guest-friendly hotel then. Again, most of the staff are great, and they have a wonderful location and rooms, and despite the issues raised we would still recommend the Ilikai for a Honolulu stay.

Admittedly, I wouldn't have stayed here if I didn't get a hook-up. And we ended up in a 2-bedroom condo on a really high floor, with ocean views and 2 bathrooms, so I'm really not complaining.The lobby of the hotel is very inviting and the staff is wonderful, helpful and friendly. The hotel is older, so the room was a bit dated. The the second "bedroom" once started off as a living room but they put sliding doors up to separate it from the living room/kitchen area. The master bedroom suite was nice enough, with a lanai that looked out over the the HHV, but was pleasant. (Let's face it - when you're in Hawaii, you're not spending much time in your hotel room anyway, unless you're on your honeymoon. I was there with my husband, my 2 year old son and my parents...)The location is nice. Right next door to the Hilton Hawaiian Village, not too far from Waikiki, next door to Morimoto's Waikiki. You don't have to fight the hustle and bustle of the tourists.The bad points for me were:1. The hotel is frequented by seniors mostly. The pool area is not meant for children. We didn't stay for too long (and only went once) because I was afraid my son would make too much noise for all of the seniors at the pool.2. No beach. (Enough said.)3. The restaurant/bar at the hotel wasn't quite up to par. Our food took forever to get to us, and it was just bar food. And their "luau" was a joke. The food was decent enough but the set up was just not right. The music and atmosphere was nice enough. But the brightest spot about their luau was that you can see the HHV fireworks show from right where we were sitting.All in all, the hotel is nice enough to sleep at, but other activities should be done elsewhere. If you're looking for full-amenities, this is the wrong place for you.

Stayed at Ilikai Resort July 18-25, 2011 and was very satisfied. Great large balcony and was nice to have harbor/ocean view room (was on 24th floor) vs. city or mountain view as you can watch the surfing and sailboats/motorboats cruising along with them coming in and out of the adjacent Ala Wai Harbor. Nice beach is 3 min walk and Marina is right outside back of hotel. Open-air casual dining w/bar location along with higher end Italian eatery is on premises. 3 major rental car agencies, mini markets, bus stop, trollies, asst. eateries as Charthouse, a sportsbar, McDonalds, etc. are within 100 yards of hotel. If renting a car (and on budget), it's recommended to rent car in morning on a 1 day basis and return to rental agency that evening by 7 pm to not have to pay $22.00 valet parking fee per day at hotel. Both free and metered parking is available around hotel but is a gamble being a very busy area. Taxis are always lined up at hotel front and OK if you plan to do go any distance. Though not really a "city bus person", my 2 friends and I did use them for some local jaunts to areas within about 30 min of hotels. Running approx every 20-30 min at $2.50 with one any direction transfer worked out great between our 2 day car rental (drove around most of island incl. N. Shore) and walks. Some mid/high end retail stores are right down the street from hotel and can be comfortably walked.

This is a great hotel for beach activities and shopping. The room is very spacious and clean with breathtaking views. It is so close to the beach and the lagoon. The Huge shopping mall is just about ten minutes walking distance to the hotel. Unfortunately we got there too late, most of the shops were closed. The big pool bed at the swimming pool was simply divine. The staff were very friendly.

We stayed at the Ilikai hotel for 2 nights after a cruise and really liked it. We requested an oceanview room thru Blue Hawaii and it was very nice. We've heard about hotel rooms being small in Waikiki but this room was huge. It had a large flatscreen tv on the wall, a fridge, microwave, coffee maker, safe, ironing board, free wi-fi in room, nice lanai/balcony and 2 separate showers. One bathtub with a shower and a separate room with a toilet & standing shower so both of us could use the shower at the same time. Their parking is $22 valet only but their service was really good. We had a porter meet us and hold our bags when we arrived in the morning before check in. We went and toured Honolulu until we could check in at 3pm and he delivered our bags to our room. He got us ice and said if there is anything you need to make your stay with us great, just let me know. Thumbs up!

This was our second visit to the ilikai, and its had a bit of a face lift. We were a family with a 2 year boy, so booked ina 2 bedroom suite with sea view. The second room is partioned off by sliding doors but was ample for our needs. The full kitchen allowed us to cook when we required. Its in a great location, being at the quiet end of the beach. Its a 10 minute walk to the AlaMoana shopping centre, which is noted for its shops but we should also note the food court has some great "restaraunts", with takeaway food. The supermarket has a great range of cooked or prepared meals. They ask you for your phone number, just give it to them as this enrolls you in their club, which provides instant discounts. From then on just mention your phone number and they will apply the discounts.Across the road from the hotel are a number of restaraunts and bars. The bar downstairs is a great wee local, with $5 breakfasts. The buffalo wings bar is large and focuses on the sports and varsity crowds. great basic food and is set up for kids. There are 2 car rental companies alamo and national. while they have a gfreat range of cars i would recommend booking online to get a better discount. You can park behind the ilikai at the wharf for $12 for 24 hours, and its only a 2 minute walk to the hotel. If you're keen on shopping there is a bus stop outside the ilikai which takes you the Waikele Outlet centre and return for $5. be early as its popular, but luckily this is the first stop on both journeys. There is a new coffee shop in the ilikai which made ok coffee (please note kiwis are coffee snobs and everybody else thought it was great), but had great cakes and nibbles. The swimming pool is heated as we later found out and my 2 year old definitely preferred that compared to the sea. there are a number of elderly ladies who come down to the pool from their condo's in the early morning, and they're a great source of information and fun. There are 2 ABC stores basically next to the hotel. The one diagonally across the road is a specialist fruit and vegetable shop so great source of fresh food. booze was cheap in these stores. I bought some New Zealand beers for less than what i would pay in NZ, whats that all about! We probably won't be back for awhile as we'll try new places but i can thoroughly recommend the ilika. The staff were all great (thanks tammy for sorting out my problem with the international date line and having a booking for the day AFTER we arrived). Right next door is the Hilton and they welcome you to their restaraunts but not the pools. great location and value for money

We have stayed at the Ilikai many times and always in a different condo. The Ilikai has changed owners about 3 or 4 times since we started going there and it has seen some ups and downs. One year we went there and the shops, pool and restaurants were closed and it looked very neglected. We were there again in May and I have to say that it is looking more like its former self. I really think the new hotel "Edition" in what was once part of the Ilikai has really helped a lot.. It is a lovely place for couple or families and you could not ask for better views and being so close to the ocean is wonderful. It is cheaper to rent a condo than to stay through the hotel directly and of course you have full kitchens so can control your budget a little better. we just love the fact that after a long day out or in the water it is nice to come back and relax and you don't have to go out to eat if you don't want to.We have friends that stay at other hotels along Waikiki and we have also stayed at other hotels but the beach is so less crowded down by the Ilikai and you are close to the Mall, the locals beach, Magic Island and of course you can enjoy the Hilton Hawaiian at night with all the lovely trees lit up or go see the penguins or flamingoes or the beautiful koi pnds they have throughout the grounds. We love to walk up town at night which only takes about 10 minutes and then walk your dinner off on the way back to the hotel.There are 11 of us going back in November and we are staying at the Ilikai hotel and the Ilikai Marina. I can't wait; we always have such a wonderful time.Favourite retaurants to go to; Cheesecake Factory and Bubba Gump Shrimp; absolutely delicious.

We stayed here for the location and the reasonable prices. Our complaint was that the rooms that are called "2 bedrooms" only have sliding panels for the "second bedroom".
